title: Paul Scholes identifies moment 'alarm bells started ringing' under Ed Woodward at Man Utd
text:

Paul Scholes says the current issues at Manchester United have been apparent from the moment Ed Woodward took his executive vice-chairman role, and the club began signing players like Marouane Fellaini and Juan Mata.

Woodward succeeded David Gill in the top operating role at Old Trafford in the summer of 2013, when Sir Alex Ferguson also left the club.

Ferguson and Gill had overseen the latter half of the legendary Scot's glorious reign as manager, with Gill being promoted to chief executive in 2003.

But when the pair left and were succeeded by Woodward and new manager David Moyes, that was when the "alarm bells rang" for club legend Scholes, who had also just walked away from the club having come back for a second spell after retirement.

(Image: Getty Images)

With United languishing in 12th under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, former midfielder Scholes was asked how long he thinks it will be before the club return to their former glories by Robbie Savage on Radio Five Live.

"I think four or five transfer windows, and they have to be good transfer windows," said Scholes.

"Ole's first three signings have been good and promising. As long as he is in charge of the players coming in, I don't see a problem.

(Image: PA)

"We hope it goes to back challenging for titles and Champions Leagues. When you look five or six years ago when Alex left, the other person who didn't get the credit he deserved was David Gill. He was a football man and he knew footballers.

"From the day he and Sir Alex left, it has been difficult.

"I think the alarm bells rang straight away when David (Moyes) took over and signed Juan Mata and Marouane Fellaini for £70m.

(Image: Internet Unknown)

"They are good players but I don't think they were Man Utd players. I don't think Sir Alex and David Gill would have signed those players.

"We are in this position now because we have signed players who are not Man Utd players.

"Ole is in there now and trying to put it right."
description: The club's former midfielder says things have been going wrong at the club since Woodward took up the executive vice-chairman role in 2013
